summary: This is an email chain from June 29, 2020, between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel discussing the need to obtain a new court order to disclose additional Epstein-related trust agreements beyond those covered by a prior February 2020 order. The correspondence references legal procedures under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 6(e) and concerns about privacy and protective orders.

persons.name: John McEnany
persons.context: Appears as an email participant from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, discussing the legal procedure for obtaining a new court order to disclose Epstein trust agreements.

persons.name: Ted
persons.context: Mentioned in reference to an email he sent with an attached court order regarding the disclosure of Epstein trust agreements.

events.title: Issuance of second 6(e) order
events.description: A court order from February 2020 allowed the Civil division to review additional Epstein trust agreements beyond those referenced in a prior order.

events.title: Discussion on need for new disclosure order
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office personnel correspond about the necessity to apply for a new court order to further disclose Epstein trust agreements, addressing privacy concerns and potential protective orders.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was seeking to disclose additional Epstein-related trust agreements beyond what was permitted by a February 2020 court order.
The legal discussion centers on Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 6(e), which governs the secrecy of grand jury proceedings and the disclosure of related materials.
The correspondence indicates concerns about privacy and the potential need for protective orders when disclosing the trust agreements.
There is consideration about whether to give notice to the people from whom the trust agreements were obtained.
